overview_of_class: This course interrogates the body to analyze the ways formations of violence are mediated by race, sexuality, and gender, and how space informs how violence is theorized and understood. Students will engage with different types of texts, ranging from film to court trial transcripts, to interrogate what constitutes the body and the sociocultural practices that inscribe differential meanings onto it. One of the main objectives of this course is not only to analyze obvious sites of subjugation, but also to locate and make legible those sites in which the violence and multi-levels of subjectivity are misrecognized, misinterpreted, and made illegible. Within this framework, students will critically reflect on the relationship between the body, space, identity formation, and notions of belonging. We will give attention to the body as a site of knowledge that resists and contests different forms of violence and repression.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. To critically understand and articulate the relationship between the body, violence, and space.

2. To define and analyze violence, and the historical and contemporary processes of erasure and misrepresentation.

3. To locate and critically ground academic concepts regarding body politics, and how heteropatriarchal constructs of race, sexuality, and gender are mobilized to inscribe differential meanings onto bodies.

4. To identify and critically articulate different modes of bodily praxis resist violence and contest dominant understandings of what is understood as violence.

5. To rigorously demonstrate active learning and application of theories and concepts through written form and other creative forms of expression.
